metadata.title: Kernel "vm.mmap_min_addr" Parameter Configuration and Runtime Check
metadata.description: The "vm.mmap_min_addr" kernel parameter should be set to the appropriate value in both system configuration and system runtime.

metadata.title: Kernel "vm.mmap_min_addr" Parameter Configuration Check
metadata.description: The kernel "vm.mmap_min_addr" parameter should be set to "65536" in the system configuration.

criterion.comment: kernel static parameter vm.mmap_min_addr set to 65536 in /etc/sysctl.conf
kernel static parameter vm.mmap_min_addr set to 65536 in /etc/sysctl.d/*.conf
kernel static parameter vm.mmap_min_addr set to 65536 in /run/sysctl.d/*.conf
kernel static parameter vm.mmap_min_addr set to 65536 in /usr/lib/sysctl.d/*.conf

metadata.title: Set ClientAliveCountMax for User Logins
metadata.description: The SSH ClientAliveCountMax should be set to an appropriate value (and dependencies are met)

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

criterion.comment: Check ClientAliveCountMax in /etc/ssh/sshd_config

metadata.title: Set OpenSSH Idle Timeout Interval
metadata.description: The SSH idle timeout interval should be set to an appropriate value.

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

criterion.comment: Check ClientAliveInterval in /etc/ssh/sshd_config

metadata.title: Disable root Login via SSH
metadata.description: Root login via SSH should be disabled (and dependencies are met)

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

criterion.comment: Check PermitRootLogin in /etc/ssh/sshd_config

metadata.title: Disable Empty Passwords
metadata.description: Remote connections from accounts with empty passwords should be disabled (and dependencies are met)

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

criterion.comment: Check PermitEmptyPasswords in /etc/ssh/sshd_config

metadata.title: Ensure Only Protocol 2 Connections Allowed
metadata.description: The OpenSSH daemon should be running protocol 2.

criteria.comment: SSH is not being used or conditions are met

criterion.comment: Check Protocol in /etc/ssh/sshd_config

metadata.title: SNMP use newer protocols
metadata.description: SNMP version 1 and 2c must not be enabled.

criterion.comment: SNMP protocols

metadata.title: SNMP default communities disabled
metadata.description: SNMP default communities must be removed.

criterion.comment: SNMP communities

metadata.title: Service sshd Disabled
metadata.description: The sshd service should be disabled if possible.

criteria.comment: package openssh-server removed or service sshd is not configured to start
service sshd is not configured to start

criterion.comment: sshd not wanted by multi-user.target

metadata.title: Service rsyslog Enabled
metadata.description: The rsyslog service should be enabled if possible.

criteria.comment: package rsyslog installed and service rsyslog is configured to start
service rsyslog is configured to start

criterion.comment: multi-user.target wants rsyslog

metadata.title: Service ntpd Enabled
metadata.description: The ntpd service should be enabled if possible.

criteria.comment: package ntp installed and service ntpd is configured to start
service ntpd is configured to start

criterion.comment: multi-user.target wants ntpd

metadata.title: Service cron Enabled
metadata.description: The cron service should be enabled if possible.

criteria.comment: package cron installed and service cron is configured to start
service cron is configured to start

criterion.comment: multi-user.target wants cron

metadata.title: Service auditd Enabled
metadata.description: The auditd service should be enabled if possible.

criteria.comment: package auditd installed and service auditd is configured to start
service auditd is configured to start

criterion.comment: multi-user.target wants auditd

metadata.title: Restrict Virtual Console Root Logins
metadata.description: Preventing direct root login to virtual console devices helps ensure accountability for actions taken on the system using the root account.

criterion.comment: virtual consoles /etc/securetty

metadata.title: Send Logs to a Remote Loghost
metadata.description: Syslog logs should be sent to a remote loghost

criterion.comment: Remote logging set within /etc/rsyslog.conf
Remote logging set within /etc/rsyslog.d

metadata.title: Confirm Existence and Permissions of System Log Files
metadata.description: File permissions for all syslog log files should be set correctly.

criterion.comment: Check permissions of all system log files

metadata.title: Confirm Existence and Permissions of System Log Files
metadata.description: All syslog log files should be owned by the appropriate user.

criterion.comment: Check if all system log files are owned by root user

metadata.title: Confirm Existence and Permissions of System Log Files
metadata.description: All syslog log files should be owned by the appropriate group.

criterion.comment: Check if all system log files are owned by root group

metadata.title: Restrict Serial Port Root Logins
metadata.description: Preventing direct root login to serial port interfaces helps ensure accountability for actions taken on the system using the root account.

criterion.comment: serial ports /etc/securetty

metadata.title: Ensure /var/log/audit Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: Audit logs are stored in the /var/log/audit directory. Ensure that it has its own partition or logical volume. Make absolutely certain that it is large enough to store all audit logs that will be created by the auditing daemon.

criterion.comment: /var/log/audit on own partition

metadata.title: Ensure /var/log Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: System logs are stored in the /var/log directory. Ensure that it has its own partition or logical volume.

criterion.comment: /var/log on own partition

metadata.title: Ensure /var Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: Ensuring that /var is mounted on its own partition enables the setting of more restrictive mount options, which is used as temporary storage by many program, particularly system services such as daemons. It is not uncommon for the /var directory to contain world-writable directories, installed by other software packages.

criterion.comment: /var on own partition

metadata.title: Ensure /tmp Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: The /tmp directory is a world-writable directory used for temporary file storage. Verify that it has its own partition or logical volume.

criterion.comment: /tmp on own partition

metadata.title: Ensure /srv Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: If a file server (FTP, TFTP...) is hosted locally, create a separate partition for /srv at installation time (or migrate it later using LVM). If /srv will be mounted from another system such as an NFS server, then creating a separate partition is not necessary at installation time, and the mountpoint can instead be configured later.

criterion.comment: /srv on own partition

metadata.title: Ensure /home Located On Separate Partition
metadata.description: If user home directories will be stored locally, create a separate partition for /home. If /home will be mounted from another system such as an NFS server, then creating a separate partition is not necessary at this time, and the mountpoint can instead be configured later.

criterion.comment: /home on own partition

metadata.title: System Accounts Do Not Run a Shell
metadata.description: The root account is the only system account that should have a login shell.

criterion.comment: Test SYS_UID_MIN not defined in /etc/login.defs
Test SYS_UID_MAX not defined in /etc/login.defs
Test shell defined for UID from <0, UID_MIN -1>
Test SYS_UID_MIN defined in /etc/login.defs
Test SYS_UID_MAX defined in /etc/login.defs
Test shell defined for reserved system UIDs
Test shell defined for dynamically allocated system UIDs

metadata.title: Verify No netrc Files Exist
metadata.description: The .netrc files contain login information used to auto-login into FTP servers and reside in the user's home directory. Any .netrc files should be removed.

metadata.title: Ensure insecure_locks is disabled
metadata.description: Allowing insecure file locking could allow for sensitive data to be viewed or edited by an unauthorized user.

criterion.comment: Check for insecure NFS locks in /etc/exports

metadata.title: No nullok Option in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
metadata.description: The file /etc/pam.d/system-auth should not contain the nullok option

criterion.comment: make sure the nullok option is not used in /etc/pam.d/system-auth

metadata.title: Direct root Logins Not Allowed
metadata.description: Preventing direct root logins help ensure accountability for actions taken on the system using the root account.

criterion.comment: serial ports /etc/securetty
serial ports /etc/securetty

metadata.title: Verify that System.map files are readable only by root
metadata.description: Checks that /boot/System.map-* are only readable by root.

metadata.title: Proper Permissions User Home Directories
metadata.description: File permissions should be set correctly for the home directories for all user accounts.

criterion.comment: home directories

metadata.title: Verify /etc/shadow Permissions
metadata.description: This test makes sure that /etc/shadow is owned by 0, group owned by 42, and has mode 0640. If the target file or directory has an extended ACL then it will fail the mode check.

metadata.title: Verify /etc/passwd Permissions
metadata.description: This test makes sure that /etc/passwd is owned by 0, group owned by 0, and has mode 0644. If the target file or directory has an extended ACL then it will fail the mode check.

metadata.title: Verify /etc/gshadow Permissions
metadata.description: This test makes sure that /etc/gshadow is owned by 0, group owned by 42, and has mode 0640. If the target file or directory has an extended ACL then it will fail the mode check.

metadata.title: Verify /etc/group Permissions
metadata.description: This test makes sure that /etc/group is owned by 0, group owned by 0, and has mode 0644. If the target file or directory has an extended ACL then it will fail the mode check.

metadata.title: Verify /var/log/audit Ownership
metadata.description: Checks that all /var/log/audit files and directories are owned by the root user and group.

criteria.comment: directories are root owned
log_group in auditd.conf is not root

metadata.title: Ensure the logrotate utility performs the automatic rotation of log files on daily basis
metadata.description: The frequency of automatic log files rotation performed by the logrotate utility should be configured to run daily

criteria.comment: /etc/logrotate.conf contains daily setting or /etc/cron.daily/logrotate file exists

criterion.comment: Check if daily is set in /etc/logrotate.conf
Check if /etc/cron.daily/logrotate file exists (and calls logrotate)

metadata.title: Ensure Yum gpgcheck Globally Activated
metadata.description: The gpgcheck option should be used to ensure that checking of an RPM package's signature always occurs prior to its installation.

criterion.comment: check value of gpgcheck in /etc/dnf/dnf.conf
check value of gpgcheck in /etc/yum.conf

metadata.description: space_left_action setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to a certain action

criterion.comment: space_left_action setting in auditd.conf

metadata.title: Auditd Maximum Number of Logs to Retain
metadata.description: num_logs setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to at least a certain value

criterion.comment: num_logs setting in auditd.conf

metadata.description: max_log_file_action setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to a certain action

metadata.title: Auditd Maximum Log File Size
metadata.description: max_log_file setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to at least a certain value

metadata.title: Auditd Action to Take When Disk is Low on Space
metadata.description: admin_space_left_action setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to a certain action

criterion.comment: admin_space_left_action setting in auditd.conf

metadata.description: action_mail_acct setting in /etc/audit/auditd.conf is set to a certain account

criterion.comment: action_mail_acct setting in auditd.conf

metadata.title: The syslog Plugin Of the Audit Event Multiplexor (audispd) Is Activated
metadata.description: active setting in /etc/audisp/plugins.d/syslog.conf is set to 'yes'

criterion.comment: active setting in syslog.conf

metadata.title: Write permissions are disabled for group and other in all directories in Root's Path
metadata.description: Check each directory in root's path and make use it does not grant write permission to group and other

criteria.comment: Check that write permission to group and other in root's path is denied

criterion.comment: Check for write permission to group and other in root's path

metadata.title: Lock out account after failed login attempts
metadata.description: The number of allowed failed logins should be set correctly.

criterion.comment: pam_faillock.so preauth silent set in system-auth
pam_faillock.so authfail deny value set in system-auth
pam_faillock.so set in account phase of system-auth
pam_faillock.so preauth silent set in password-auth
pam_faillock.so authfail deny value set in password-auth
pam_faillock.so set in account phase of password-auth

metadata.title: Set Password Expiration Parameters
metadata.description: The password expiration warning age should be set appropriately.

metadata.title: Set Password Expiration Parameters
metadata.description: The password minimum length should be set appropriately.

metadata.title: All Password Hashes Shadowed
metadata.description: All password hashes should be shadowed.

criterion.comment: password hashes are shadowed

metadata.title: UID 0 Belongs Only To Root
metadata.description: Only the root account should be assigned a user id of 0.

criterion.comment: tests that there are no accounts with UID 0 except root in the /etc/passwd file

metadata.title: Set Password Expiration Parameters
metadata.description: The minimum password age policy should be set appropriately.

criteria.comment: The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs

metadata.title: Set Password Expiration Parameters
metadata.description: The maximum password age policy should meet minimum requirements.

criteria.comment: The value PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs

metadata.title: Set All Accounts To Have Unique Names
metadata.description: All accounts on the system should have unique names for proper accountability.

criteria.comment: There should not exist duplicate user name entries in /etc/passwd

ind-def:family_test.comment: installed OS part of unix family

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Tests the value of the PermitRootLogin[\s]*(<:nocomment:>*) setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file
Tests the value of the PermitEmptyPasswords[\s]*(<:nocomment:>*) setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file
Tests the value of the ClientAliveCountMax setting in the /etc/ssh/sshd_config file

ind-def:variable_test.comment: <0, SYS_UID_MIN> system UIDs having shell set
<SYS_UID_MIN, SYS_UID_MAX> system UIDS having shell set
<0, UID_MIN - 1> system UIDs having shell set

unix-def:sysctl_test.comment: kernel runtime parameter vm.mmap_min_addr set to 65536
kernel runtime parameter net.ipv4.ip_forward set to the appropriate value
kernel runtime parameter kernel.sysrq set to 0
kernel runtime parameter kernel.randomize_va_space set to 2
kernel runtime parameter kernel.pid_max set to 65536
kernel runtime parameter kernel.perf_event_paranoid set to 2
kernel runtime parameter kernel.perf_event_max_sample_rate set to 1
kernel runtime parameter kernel.perf_cpu_time_max_percent set to 1
kernel runtime parameter kernel.kptr_restrict set to 1
kernel runtime parameter kernel.dmesg_restrict set to 1
kernel runtime parameter fs.suid_dumpable set to 0
kernel runtime parameter fs.protected_symlinks set to 1
kernel runtime parameter fs.protected_hardlinks set to 1

unix-def:file_test.comment: Permissions of system log files are 0640
System log files are owned by root
System log files are owned by root group

ind-def:family_test.comment: installed OS part of unix family

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Ensures system configured to export logs to remote host
Ensures system configured to export logs to remote host

unix-def:file_test.comment: system.map files readable only by root

ind-def:variable_test.comment: The value of PASS_WARN_AGE should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
The value of PASS_MIN_LEN should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
The value of PASS_MIN_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs
The value of PASS_MAX_DAYS should be set appropriately in /etc/login.defs

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Tests the value of the insecure locks in /etc/exports
make sure nullok is not used in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Tests the presence of daily setting in /etc/logrotate.conf file
CPE vendor is 'fedoraproject' and 'product' is fedora

ind-def:variable_test.comment: There should not exist duplicate user name entries in /etc/passwd

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Tests the existence of /etc/cron.daily/logrotate file (and verify it actually calls logrotate utility)

unix-def:file_test.comment: Check if there aren't directories in root's path having write permission set for group or other

ind-def:textfilecontent54_test.comment: Check pam_faillock.so preauth silent present in /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check pam_faillock.so preauth silent present in /etc/pam.d/password-auth
Check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/system-auth (authfail)
Check maximum failed login attempts allowed in /etc/pam.d/password-auth (authfail)
Check if pam_faillock_so is called in account phase of /etc/pam.d/system-auth
Check if pam_faillock_so is called in account phase of /etc/pam.d/password-auth
test that there are no accounts with UID 0 except root in the /etc/passwd file

unix-def:file_object.comment: root's path directories with wrong group / other write permissions

ind-def:textfilecontent54_state.comment: upper bound of ClientAliveInterval in seconds
lower bound of ClientAliveInterval in seconds

lin-def:systemdunitdependency_state.comment: sshd is not listed in the dependencies
rsyslog listed at least once in the dependencies
ntpd listed at least once in the dependencies
cron listed at least once in the dependencies
auditd listed at least once in the dependencies

unix-def:file_state.comment: group or other has write privilege

local_variable.comment: Value of last UID_MIN from /etc/login.defs
UIDs retrieved from /etc/passwd
Value of last SYS_UID_MIN from /etc/login.defs
Value of last SYS_UID_MAX from /etc/login.defs
Construct (x - 0) * (x - SYS_UID_MIN) expression
The value of last PASS_WARN_AGE directive in /etc/login.defs
The value of last PASS_MIN_LEN directive in /etc/login.defs
The value of last PASS_MIN_DAYS directive in /etc/login.defs
The value of last PASS_MAX_DAYS directive in /etc/login.defs
Construct (x - SYS_UID_MIN) * (x - SYS_UID_MAX) expression
Construct (x - 0) * (x - (UID_MIN - 1)) expression
Count of unique username rows retrieved from /etc/passwd
Count of all username rows retrieved from /etc/passwd (including duplicates if any)
File paths of all rsyslog configuration files
$IncludeConfig value converted to regex
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files concatenated into string
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files as collection
File paths of all rsyslog configuration files
$IncludeConfig value converted to regex
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files concatenated into string
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files as collection
File paths of all rsyslog configuration files
$IncludeConfig value converted to regex
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files concatenated into string
Locations of all rsyslog configuration files as collection
Split the PATH on the : delimiter

external_variable.comment: number of failed login attempts allowed
password expiration warning age in days

object.message: There was a problem processing referenced variable (oval:ssg-var_accounts_root_path_dirs_no_write:v

ind-sys:textfilecontent_item.ind-sys:text:
# # /etc/login.defs - Configuration control definitions for the login package. # # Three items must be defined: MAIL_DIR, ENV_SUPATH, and ENV_PATH. # If unspecified, some arbitrary (and possibly incorrect) value will # be assumed. All other items are optional - if not specified then # the described action or option will be inhibited. # # Comment lines (lines beginning with "#") and blank lines are ignored. # # Modified for Linux. --marekm
# REQUIRED for useradd/userdel/usermod # Directory where mailboxes reside, _or_ name of file, relative to the # home directory. If you _do_ define MAIL_DIR and MAIL_FILE, # MAIL_DIR takes precedence. # # Essentially: # - MAIL_DIR defines the location of users mail spool files # (for mbox use) by appending the username to MAIL_DIR as defined # below. # - MAIL_FILE defines the location of the users mail spool files as the # fully-qualified filename obtained by prepending the user home # directory before $MAIL_FILE # # NOTE: This is no more used for setting up users MAIL environment variable # which is, starting from shadow 4.0.12-1 in Debian, entirely the # job of the pam_mail PAM modules # See default PAM configuration files provided for # login, su, etc. # # This is a temporary situation: setting these variables will soon # move to /etc/default/useradd and the variables will then be # no more supported MAIL_DIR /var/mail #MAIL_FILE .mail
# # Enable logging and display of /var/log/faillog login failure info. # This option conflicts with the pam_tally PAM module. # FAILLOG_ENAB yes
# # Enable display of unknown usernames when login failures are recorded. # # WARNING: Unknown usernames may become world readable. # See #290803 and #298773 for details about how this could become a security # concern LOG_UNKFAIL_ENAB no
# # Enable logging of successful logins # LOG_OK_LOGINS no
# # Enable "syslog" logging of su activity - in addition to sulog file logging. # SYSLOG_SG_ENAB does the same for newgrp and sg. # SYSLOG_SU_ENAB yes SYSLOG_SG_ENAB yes
# # If defined, all su activity is logged to this file. # #SULOG_FILE /var/log/sulog
# # If defined, file which maps tty line to TERM environment parameter. # Each line of the file is in a format something like "vt100 tty01". # #TTYTYPE_FILE /etc/ttytype
# # If defined, login failures will be logged here in a utmp format # last, when invoked as lastb, will read /var/log/btmp, so... # FTMP_FILE /var/log/btmp
# # If defined, the command name to display when running "su -". For # example, if this is defined as "su" then a "ps" will display the # command is "-su". If not defined, then "ps" would display the # name of the shell actually being run, e.g. something like "-sh". # SU_NAME su
# # If defined, file which inhibits all the usual chatter during the login # sequence. If a full pathname, then hushed mode will be enabled if the # user's name or shell are found in the file. If not a full pathname, then # hushed mode will be enabled if the file exists in the user's home directory. # HUSHLOGIN_FILE .hushlogin #HUSHLOGIN_FILE /etc/hushlogins
# # *REQUIRED* The default PATH settings, for superuser and normal users. # # (they are minimal, add the rest in the shell startup files) ENV_SUPATH PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin ENV_PATH PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games
# # Terminal permissions # # TTYGROUP Login tty will be assigned this group ownership. # TTYPERM Login tty will be set to this permission. # # If you have a "write" program which is "setgid" to a special group # which owns the terminals, define TTYGROUP to the group number and # TTYPERM to 0620. Otherwise leave TTYGROUP commented out and assign # TTYPERM to either 622 or 600. # # In Debian /usr/bin/bsd-write or similar programs are setgid tty # However, the default and recommended value for TTYPERM is still 0600 # to not allow anyone to write to anyone else console or terminal
# Users can still allow other people to write them by issuing # the "mesg y" command.
TTYGROUP tty TTYPERM 0600
# # Login configuration initializations: # # ERASECHAR Terminal ERASE character ('\010' = backspace). # KILLCHAR Terminal KILL character ('\025' = CTRL/U). # UMASK Default "umask" value. # # The ERASECHAR and KILLCHAR are used only on System V machines. # # UMASK is the default umask value for pam_umask and is used by # useradd and newusers to set the mode of the new home directories. # 022 is the "historical" value in Debian for UMASK # 027, or even 077, could be considered better for privacy # There is no One True Answer here : each sysadmin must make up his/her # mind. # # If USERGROUPS_ENAB is set to "yes", that will modify this UMASK default value # for private user groups, i. e. the uid is the same as gid, and username is # the same as the primary group name: for these, the user permissions will be # used as group permissions, e. g. 022 will become 002. # # Prefix these values with "0" to get octal, "0x" to get hexadecimal. # ERASECHAR 0177 KILLCHAR 025 UMASK 022
# # Password aging controls: # # PASS_MAX_DAYS Maximum number of days a password may be used. # PASS_MIN_DAYS Minimum number of days allowed between password changes. # PASS_WARN_AGE Number of days warning given before a password expires. # PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999 PASS_MIN_DAYS 0 PASS_WARN_AGE 7
# # Min/max values for automatic uid selection in useradd # UID_MIN 1000

# # /etc/login.defs - Configuration control definitions for the login package. # # Three items must be defined: MAIL_DIR, ENV_SUPATH, and ENV_PATH. # If unspecified, some arbitrary (and possibly incorrect) value will # be assumed. All other items are optional - if not specified then # the described action or option will be inhibited. # # Comment lines (lines beginning with "#") and blank lines are ignored. # # Modified for Linux. --marekm
# REQUIRED for useradd/userdel/usermod # Directory where mailboxes reside, _or_ name of file, relative to the # home directory. If you _do_ define MAIL_DIR and MAIL_FILE, # MAIL_DIR takes precedence. # # Essentially: # - MAIL_DIR defines the location of users mail spool files # (for mbox use) by appending the username to MAIL_DIR as defined # below. # - MAIL_FILE defines the location of the users mail spool files as the # fully-qualified filename obtained by prepending the user home # directory before $MAIL_FILE # # NOTE: This is no more used for setting up users MAIL environment variable # which is, starting from shadow 4.0.12-1 in Debian, entirely the # job of the pam_mail PAM modules # See default PAM configuration files provided for # login, su, etc. # # This is a temporary situation: setting these variables will soon # move to /etc/default/useradd and the variables will then be # no more supported MAIL_DIR /var/mail #MAIL_FILE .mail
# # Enable logging and display of /var/log/faillog login failure info. # This option conflicts with the pam_tally PAM module. # FAILLOG_ENAB yes
# # Enable display of unknown usernames when login failures are recorded. # # WARNING: Unknown usernames may become world readable. # See #290803 and #298773 for details about how this could become a security # concern LOG_UNKFAIL_ENAB no
# # Enable logging of successful logins # LOG_OK_LOGINS no
# # Enable "syslog" logging of su activity - in addition to sulog file logging. # SYSLOG_SG_ENAB does the same for newgrp and sg. # SYSLOG_SU_ENAB yes SYSLOG_SG_ENAB yes
# # If defined, all su activity is logged to this file. # #SULOG_FILE /var/log/sulog
# # If defined, file which maps tty line to TERM environment parameter. # Each line of the file is in a format something like "vt100 tty01". # #TTYTYPE_FILE /etc/ttytype
# # If defined, login failures will be logged here in a utmp format # last, when invoked as lastb, will read /var/log/btmp, so... # FTMP_FILE /var/log/btmp
# # If defined, the command name to display when running "su -". For # example, if this is defined as "su" then a "ps" will display the # command is "-su". If not defined, then "ps" would display the # name of the shell actually being run, e.g. something like "-sh". # SU_NAME su
# # If defined, file which inhibits all the usual chatter during the login # sequence. If a full pathname, then hushed mode will be enabled if the # user's name or shell are found in the file. If not a full pathname, then # hushed mode will be enabled if the file exists in the user's home directory. # HUSHLOGIN_FILE .hushlogin #HUSHLOGIN_FILE /etc/hushlogins
# # *REQUIRED* The default PATH settings, for superuser and normal users. # # (they are minimal, add the rest in the shell startup files) ENV_SUPATH PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin ENV_PATH PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games
# # Terminal permissions # # TTYGROUP Login tty will be assigned this group ownership. # TTYPERM Login tty will be set to this permission. # # If you have a "write" program which is "setgid" to a special group # which owns the terminals, define TTYGROUP to the group number and # TTYPERM to 0620. Otherwise leave TTYGROUP commented out and assign # TTYPERM to either 622 or 600. # # In Debian /usr/bin/bsd-write or similar programs are setgid tty # However, the default and recommended value for TTYPERM is still 0600 # to not allow anyone to write to anyone else console or terminal
# Users can still allow other people to write them by issuing # the "mesg y" command.
TTYGROUP tty TTYPERM 0600
# # Login configuration initializations: # # ERASECHAR Terminal ERASE character ('\010' = backspace). # KILLCHAR Terminal KILL character ('\025' = CTRL/U). # UMASK Default "umask" value. # # The ERASECHAR and KILLCHAR are used only on System V machines. # # UMASK is the default umask value for pam_umask and is used by # useradd and newusers to set the mode of the new home directories. # 022 is the "historical" value in Debian for UMASK # 027, or even 077, could be considered better for privacy # There is no One True Answer here : each sysadmin must make up his/her # mind. # # If USERGROUPS_ENAB is set to "yes", that will modify this UMASK default value # for private user groups, i. e. the uid is the same as gid, and username is # the same as the primary group name: for these, the user permissions will be # used as group permissions, e. g. 022 will become 002. # # Prefix these values with "0" to get octal, "0x" to get hexadecimal. # ERASECHAR 0177 KILLCHAR 025 UMASK 022
# # Password aging controls: # # PASS_MAX_DAYS Maximum number of days a password may be used. # PASS_MIN_DAYS Minimum number of days allowed between password changes. # PASS_WARN_AGE Number of days warning given before a password expires. # PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999

# # /etc/login.defs - Configuration control definitions for the login package. # # Three items must be defined: MAIL_DIR, ENV_SUPATH, and ENV_PATH. # If unspecified, some arbitrary (and possibly incorrect) value will # be assumed. All other items are optional - if not specified then # the described action or option will be inhibited. # # Comment lines (lines beginning with "#") and blank lines are ignored. # # Modified for Linux. --marekm
# REQUIRED for useradd/userdel/usermod # Directory where mailboxes reside, _or_ name of file, relative to the # home directory. If you _do_ define MAIL_DIR and MAIL_FILE, # MAIL_DIR takes precedence. # # Essentially: # - MAIL_DIR defines the location of users mail spool files # (for mbox use) by appending the username to MAIL_DIR as defined # below. # - MAIL_FILE defines the location of the users mail spool files as the # fully-qualified filename obtained by prepending the user home # directory before $MAIL_FILE # # NOTE: This is no more used for setting up users MAIL environment variable # which is, starting from shadow 4.0.12-1 in Debian, entirely the # job of the pam_mail PAM modules # See default PAM configuration files provided for # login, su, etc. # # This is a temporary situation: setting these variables will soon # move to /etc/default/useradd and the variables will then be # no more supported MAIL_DIR /var/mail #MAIL_FILE .mail
# # Enable logging and display of /var/log/faillog login failure info. # This option conflicts with the pam_tally PAM module. # FAILLOG_ENAB yes
# # Enable display of unknown usernames when login failures are recorded. # # WARNING: Unknown usernames may become world readable. # See #290803 and #298773 for details about how this could become a security # concern LOG_UNKFAIL_ENAB no
# # Enable logging of successful logins # LOG_OK_LOGINS no
# # Enable "syslog" logging of su activity - in addition to sulog file logging. # SYSLOG_SG_ENAB does the same for newgrp and sg. # SYSLOG_SU_ENAB yes SYSLOG_SG_ENAB yes
# # If defined, all su activity is logged to this file. # #SULOG_FILE /var/log/sulog
# # If defined, file which maps tty line to TERM environment parameter. # Each line of the file is in a format something like "vt100 tty01". # #TTYTYPE_FILE /etc/ttytype
# # If defined, login failures will be logged here in a utmp format # last, when invoked as lastb, will read /var/log/btmp, so... # FTMP_FILE /var/log/btmp
# # If defined, the command name to display when running "su -". For # example, if this is defined as "su" then a "ps" will display the # command is "-su". If not defined, then "ps" would display the # name of the shell actually being run, e.g. something like "-sh". # SU_NAME su
# # If defined, file which inhibits all the usual chatter during the login # sequence. If a full pathname, then hushed mode will be enabled if the # user's name or shell are found in the file. If not a full pathname, then # hushed mode will be enabled if the file exists in the user's home directory. # HUSHLOGIN_FILE .hushlogin #HUSHLOGIN_FILE /etc/hushlogins
# # *REQUIRED* The default PATH settings, for superuser and normal users. # # (they are minimal, add the rest in the shell startup files) ENV_SUPATH PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin ENV_PATH PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games
# # Terminal permissions # # TTYGROUP Login tty will be assigned this group ownership. # TTYPERM Login tty will be set to this permission. # # If you have a "write" program which is "setgid" to a special group # which owns the terminals, define TTYGROUP to the group number and # TTYPERM to 0620. Otherwise leave TTYGROUP commented out and assign # TTYPERM to either 622 or 600. # # In Debian /usr/bin/bsd-write or similar programs are setgid tty # However, the default and recommended value for TTYPERM is still 0600 # to not allow anyone to write to anyone else console or terminal
# Users can still allow other people to write them by issuing # the "mesg y" command.
TTYGROUP tty TTYPERM 0600
# # Login configuration initializations: # # ERASECHAR Terminal ERASE character ('\010' = backspace). # KILLCHAR Terminal KILL character ('\025' = CTRL/U). # UMASK Default "umask" value. # # The ERASECHAR and KILLCHAR are used only on System V machines. # # UMASK is the default umask value for pam_umask and is used by # useradd and newusers to set the mode of the new home directories. # 022 is the "historical" value in Debian for UMASK # 027, or even 077, could be considered better for privacy # There is no One True Answer here : each sysadmin must make up his/her # mind. # # If USERGROUPS_ENAB is set to "yes", that will modify this UMASK default value # for private user groups, i. e. the uid is the same as gid, and username is # the same as the primary group name: for these, the user permissions will be # used as group permissions, e. g. 022 will become 002. # # Prefix these values with "0" to get octal, "0x" to get hexadecimal. # ERASECHAR 0177 KILLCHAR 025 UMASK 022
# # Password aging controls: # # PASS_MAX_DAYS Maximum number of days a password may be used. # PASS_MIN_DAYS Minimum number of days allowed between password changes. # PASS_WARN_AGE Number of days warning given before a password expires. # PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999 PASS_MIN_DAYS 0

# # /etc/login.defs - Configuration control definitions for the login package. # # Three items must be defined: MAIL_DIR, ENV_SUPATH, and ENV_PATH. # If unspecified, some arbitrary (and possibly incorrect) value will # be assumed. All other items are optional - if not specified then # the described action or option will be inhibited. # # Comment lines (lines beginning with "#") and blank lines are ignored. # # Modified for Linux. --marekm
# REQUIRED for useradd/userdel/usermod # Directory where mailboxes reside, _or_ name of file, relative to the # home directory. If you _do_ define MAIL_DIR and MAIL_FILE, # MAIL_DIR takes precedence. # # Essentially: # - MAIL_DIR defines the location of users mail spool files # (for mbox use) by appending the username to MAIL_DIR as defined # below. # - MAIL_FILE defines the location of the users mail spool files as the # fully-qualified filename obtained by prepending the user home # directory before $MAIL_FILE # # NOTE: This is no more used for setting up users MAIL environment variable # which is, starting from shadow 4.0.12-1 in Debian, entirely the # job of the pam_mail PAM modules # See default PAM configuration files provided for # login, su, etc. # # This is a temporary situation: setting these variables will soon # move to /etc/default/useradd and the variables will then be # no more supported MAIL_DIR /var/mail #MAIL_FILE .mail
# # Enable logging and display of /var/log/faillog login failure info. # This option conflicts with the pam_tally PAM module. # FAILLOG_ENAB yes
# # Enable display of unknown usernames when login failures are recorded. # # WARNING: Unknown usernames may become world readable. # See #290803 and #298773 for details about how this could become a security # concern LOG_UNKFAIL_ENAB no
# # Enable logging of successful logins # LOG_OK_LOGINS no
# # Enable "syslog" logging of su activity - in addition to sulog file logging. # SYSLOG_SG_ENAB does the same for newgrp and sg. # SYSLOG_SU_ENAB yes SYSLOG_SG_ENAB yes
# # If defined, all su activity is logged to this file. # #SULOG_FILE /var/log/sulog
# # If defined, file which maps tty line to TERM environment parameter. # Each line of the file is in a format something like "vt100 tty01". # #TTYTYPE_FILE /etc/ttytype
# # If defined, login failures will be logged here in a utmp format # last, when invoked as lastb, will read /var/log/btmp, so... # FTMP_FILE /var/log/btmp
# # If defined, the command name to display when running "su -". For # example, if this is defined as "su" then a "ps" will display the # command is "-su". If not defined, then "ps" would display the # name of the shell actually being run, e.g. something like "-sh". # SU_NAME su
# # If defined, file which inhibits all the usual chatter during the login # sequence. If a full pathname, then hushed mode will be enabled if the # user's name or shell are found in the file. If not a full pathname, then # hushed mode will be enabled if the file exists in the user's home directory. # HUSHLOGIN_FILE .hushlogin #HUSHLOGIN_FILE /etc/hushlogins
# # *REQUIRED* The default PATH settings, for superuser and normal users. # # (they are minimal, add the rest in the shell startup files) ENV_SUPATH PATH=/usr/local/sbin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/sbin:/usr/bin:/sbin:/bin ENV_PATH PATH=/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/local/games:/usr/games
# # Terminal permissions # # TTYGROUP Login tty will be assigned this group ownership. # TTYPERM Login tty will be set to this permission. # # If you have a "write" program which is "setgid" to a special group # which owns the terminals, define TTYGROUP to the group number and # TTYPERM to 0620. Otherwise leave TTYGROUP commented out and assign # TTYPERM to either 622 or 600. # # In Debian /usr/bin/bsd-write or similar programs are setgid tty # However, the default and recommended value for TTYPERM is still 0600 # to not allow anyone to write to anyone else console or terminal
# Users can still allow other people to write them by issuing # the "mesg y" command.
TTYGROUP tty TTYPERM 0600
# # Login configuration initializations: # # ERASECHAR Terminal ERASE character ('\010' = backspace). # KILLCHAR Terminal KILL character ('\025' = CTRL/U). # UMASK Default "umask" value. # # The ERASECHAR and KILLCHAR are used only on System V machines. # # UMASK is the default umask value for pam_umask and is used by # useradd and newusers to set the mode of the new home directories. # 022 is the "historical" value in Debian for UMASK # 027, or even 077, could be considered better for privacy # There is no One True Answer here : each sysadmin must make up his/her # mind. # # If USERGROUPS_ENAB is set to "yes", that will modify this UMASK default value # for private user groups, i. e. the uid is the same as gid, and username is # the same as the primary group name: for these, the user permissions will be # used as group permissions, e. g. 022 will become 002. # # Prefix these values with "0" to get octal, "0x" to get hexadecimal. # ERASECHAR 0177 KILLCHAR 025 UMASK 022
# # Password aging controls: # # PASS_MAX_DAYS Maximum number of days a password may be used. # PASS_MIN_DAYS Minimum number of days allowed between password changes. # PASS_WARN_AGE Number of days warning given before a password expires. # PASS_MAX_DAYS 99999 PASS_MIN_DAYS 0 PASS_WARN_AGE 7
# /etc/securetty: list of terminals on which root is allowed to login.
